journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Modeling of rate-dependent damping capacity of one-dimensional superelastic shape memory alloys

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Engineering Mechanics, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Guansuo Dui, Institute of Engineering Mechanics, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing 100044, China. Email: gsdui@center.njtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Recent experimental tests showed that shape memory alloys have a strong dependence of stress–strain curve on the strain rate. This rate-dependent phenomenon is mainly due to the temperature variation of shape memory alloys caused by the latent heat release/absorption during the forward/reverse phase transformation. Since there is an increasing use of shape memory alloys for civil engineering like seismic application, the complex rate-dependent properties, such as the propagation stress and the damping capacity, should be carefully analyzed. This article studies the rate-dependent stress–strain curve, especially the damping capacity, of one-dimensional NiTi shape memory alloys by using a linear model and a nonlinear model taken the rate-independent driving force in the micromechanics-inspired constitutive model. Compared with the experimental data and previous work, both models use fewer material parameters and can easily describe the trend of damping capacity with respect to the strain rate. For their clear physical meaning and simple mathematical expression, both models are useful tools for the dynamic design and simulation of superelastic shape memory alloys in practice.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Shape memory alloys (SMAs) as promising “smart” materials have been widely used in aerospace, civil, mechanical, and biomedical applications, such as sensors, actuators, biomedical devices, and surgical implant materials as well as surgical instruments due to their unique shape memory effect (SME) and superior superelasticity (SE), two properties that arise from reversible martensitic transformations that can be temperature-induced or stress-induced at temperatures near room temperature (Otsuka and Wayman, 1998). In the case of the SE, the large hysteresis loop is observed in the stress–strain curve during loading and unloading. The area surrounded by the large hysteresis loop is the dissipated work per unit volume, which makes SMAs have high performance of energy absorption or damping for vibration and impact deformation. Especially, their large damping capacity (area of the hysteresis loop) is useful for improving the response of structures subjected to external force-induced vibrations (Pieczyska et al., 2005; Saadat et al., 2002).

The experimental study found that the stress–strain response of SMAs strongly depends on the strain rate (Auricchio et al., 2008; Entemeyer et al., 2000; Grabe and Bruhns, 2008; He et al., 2010; He and Sun, 2011; Leo et al., 1993; Nemat-Nasser et al., 2005; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995; Tobushi et al., 1998; Zhang et al., 2010). In order to design SMA devices and structures in which the damping capacity due to the SE are used, it is important to evaluate the properties properly and to take them into account of the design. In the reported literature, however, the trend of rate-dependent mechanical responses of SMAs, such as the stress hysteresis, is not always consistent. For the stress–strain curve of SMAs, the stress hysteresis is the value between the forward and reverse phase transformation plateaus, which directly determines the damping capacity. Some showed an increase in hysteresis with increasing rate (Leo et al., 1993; Pieczyska et al., 2005; Tobushi et al., 1998), while others showed a decrease in hysteresis with increasing rate (Dolce and Cardone, 2001; Gandhi and Wolons, 1999; Heller et al., 2009). More recent experiments (Dayananda and Subba Rao, 2008; He et al., 2010; Piedboeuf et al., 1998; Vitiello et al., 2005; Zhang et al., 2010; Zhu and Zhang, 2007) showed that the rate dependence of hysteresis is nonmonotonic with a hysteresis peak (maximum damping capacity) at an intermediate strain rate that depends on the ambient condition and geometry of the specimen.

From the thermodynamic arguments, the area enclosed by the hysteresis loop in the stress–strain plane is the energy dissipated in the loading–unloading cycle, and hysteresis is the macroscopic manifestation of energy dissipation. Many properties of hysteresis depend on the relation between two time scales: the intrinsic time scale of relaxation in the specimen (the typical time taken by the specimen to reach the nearest relative free energy minimum) and the time scale at which the specimen is driven externally. When the time scale of relaxation is comparable to the time scale of driving, hysteresis is a dynamic phenomenon, in which the driving rate plays a major role (Ortin and Delaey, 2002). A model (He and Sun, 2011) based on the temperature-dependent transformation stress (Clausius–Clapeyron relation) was proposed to study the nonmonotonic rate-dependent stress hysteresis of superelastic SMA bars and showed that such a nonmonotonic rate dependence is governed by the competition of the phase transformation time (or latent heat release/absorption time) and the characteristic relaxation time of heat exchange with the environment and that the hysteresis peak is achieved when the two time scales become comparable.

Motivated by the analyses of hysteresis and the close relationship between stress hysteresis and damping capacity, a simple linear model and a nonlinear model taken the rate-independent driving force in the micromechanics-inspired constitutive model (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007) are proposed in this article to study the rate-dependent damping capacity of one-dimensional superelastic SMAs. The simulated stress–strain curves from both models for superelastic NiTi SMAs are compared with the experimental data at various strain rates and show good agreement at low strain rates. Both models are fairly good at capturing the trend of the variation of damping capacity with respect to the strain rate. For their simplicity and fewer material parameters, both models offer a potentially useful tool for the design of SMAs damping devices and structures.

sec.title: Constitutive model for SMAs
sec.p: The micromechanics-inspired constitutive model (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007) is used in this article to build the linear model and nonlinear model for rate-dependent damping capacity of one-dimensional superelastic SMAs. The analysis of the rate-dependent properties of SMAs should consist of a mechanical law governing the stress–strain behavior, an energy balance equation that reflects the rate-dependent thermal effect and a transformation kinetics law that describes the evolution of the forward/reverse phase transformation.

sec.title: Thermodynamics formulation
sec.p: For the development of constitutive model for SMAs, the first law and second law of thermodynamics are used (Tanaka, 1986). From the first and second laws of thermodynamics, the energy balance and the Clausius–Duhem inequality in the current configuration can be written as

where u and η are the internal energy and entropy per unit mass, respectively; q and qu are the heat production and the heat flux, respectively; θ, x, and ρ are the temperature, the material coordinate, and the density in the current configuration, respectively; and σ and ε· are the stress and the velocity gradient, respectively. For simplicity, the reference configuration and the current configuration are no longer distinguished in the case of a one-dimensional small deformation in this article. The Helmholtz free energy density per unit volume ψ, function of the control variables (the strain ε and the temperature θ) and internal variables (the volume fraction of martensite λ and the effective transformation strain εm as well as the plastic strain εp), is introduced here. Substituting ψ=ψ(ε,θ,λ,εm,εp) into equation (1), an alternative version of the Clausius–Duhem inequality is obtained as
From the thermodynamics of continuous media, the coefficients of ε· and θ· should vanish in equation (2). Therefore, inequality (2) provides a set of constitutive equations as
In addition, the driving forces associated with the internal variables to be the quantities conjugate to their rates of change in equation (2) are defined as
The constitutive relation for the Helmholtz energy density of superelastic SMAs (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007) is assumed here to be

where E is the elastic modulus (assumed to be identical for austenite and martensite), ω is the difference in chemical energy between the austenite and the martensite, cp is the heat capacity (assumed to be identical for austenite and martensite), and ordinary thermal expansion is neglected. In the neighborhood of the equilibrium temperature θcr, where the chemical (or crystallographic) free energy density of the austenite and martensite is the same. Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya (2007) further assumed that the chemical part of the free energy is usually linearized by
where Λ, MS, and AS are the latent heat per unit volume, the martensite start, and austenite start temperatures, respectively. Substituting equations (5) and (6) into equations (3) and (4), we obtain

sec.title: Transformation kinetics
sec.p: The transformation kinetics of SMAs, which describes the evolution rule of martensite fraction λ for both the forward transformation from austenite to martensite and the reverse transformation from martensite to austenite, have been proposed by many researchers. Since both stress and temperature can induce phase transformation, the evolution of martensite fraction λ is often written as a function of the driving force dλ (or tensile stress σ) and the temperature θ. Generally, the phase transformation requires a critical driving force before it can proceed, that is, the rate of change of volume fraction is zero for driving forces below a critical driving force. As one exceeds the critical driving force, different evolution rules are used in the constitutive models (Brinson, 1993; Liang and Rogers, 1990; Tanaka, 1986).

The kinetic relation, where the driving force dλ is independent of the rate of phase transformation, is used in this article. Note that this rate-independent kinetic relation is consistent with the experimental observations when the driving force is low (Otsuka and Wayman, 1998), and material shows rate dependency (Nemat-Nasser et al., 2005) at large driving forces. The physical reason for the rate-independent evolution rule is a combination of metastability and pinning by defects, while the physical reason for the rate-dependent evolution rule is that phase boundaries require an unboundedly increasing driving force for the propagation speeds to reach toward some sound speed. Taken the rate-independent evolution rule as an example, when the driving force dλ increases/decreases to the critical driving force dλ+/dλ− in the forward/reverse phase transformation process, where dλ+=−ω(MS) and dλ−=−ω(AS), the macrophase transformation begins subsequently and no large/small driving force is needed until the end of martensite/austenite transformation. Substituting dλ+ and dλ− into equation (7), the tensile stresses in the forward/reverse phase transformation process are

sec.title: Physical origin of the strain rate effects and temperature evolution of SMAs
sec.p: From experimental observations (Grabe and Bruhns, 2008; Leo et al., 1993; Nemat-Nasser et al., 2005; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995), the mechanical properties of the superelastic SMAs depend on the strain rate. Shaw and Kyriakides (1995) showed that the dependence on loading rates is stronger in air than in water, and suggested that this dependence is mainly a temperature effect rather than a usual viscoelastic effect. Grabe and Bruhns (2008) confirmed this conclusion by showing that this dependence disappears if the temperature of the specimen is kept constant (isothermal tests).

The heat sources produced by the materials are often divided into two terms (Auricchio et al., 2008; Delpueyo et al., 2011; Entemeyer et al., 2000; Favier et al., 2007): (a) Htmc represents the heat production associated with the thermomechanical coupling (corresponding to the coupling between the temperature θ and the other state variables, such as strain ε and martensite fraction λ, in the expression of the free energy ψ) and (b) Dmec represents the heat production associated with the mechanical dissipation, also named intrinsic dissipation, related to any mechanical irreversible phenomena. The heat source Htmc contains at least two terms: (a) the thermoelastic coupling heat source (coupling between the temperature θ and the elastic part of the strain ε in the free energy expression ψ) and (b) the latent heat source due to phase change (coupling between the temperature θ and the volume fraction of martensite λ in the free energy expression ψ). Actually, the temperature variation is mainly caused by the latent heat source, which seems to be the predominant heat source (He and Sun, 2011; Morin et al., 2011; Ortin and Delaey, 2002; Piedboeuf et al., 1998).

For the micromechanics-inspired constitutive model used in this article (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007) and other models (Bruno et al., 1995; He and Sun, 2010, 2011; Vitiello et al., 2005; Zhu and Zhang, 2007), the latent heat of the phase transformation is simplified as a material constant, which can be easily measured through the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) thermograms for SMAs (Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995).

At a high strain rate, the internal heat may not have enough time to dissipate, and this will change the sample temperature. From the well-known Clausius–Clapeyron relation, a higher stress level is required to pursue the forward transformation if the specimen temperature increases in the loading process, and a lower stress level is needed to go on with the reverse transformation if the specimen temperature decreases in the unloading process (Bruno et al., 1995; He and Sun, 2010; Iadicola and Shaw, 2004; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1997). The presence of such effects is shown in Figure 1. Note that the effective transformation strain εm proposed in the micromechanics-inspired constitutive model is essentially equal to the phase transformation strain εT under uniaxial tension (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of effects of the loading rate on stress–strain curve.

sec.p: Generally, the occurrence of the localization of the martensitic transformation in NiTi SMAs makes a nonhomogeneous temperature field inside the polycrystalline SMAs, and the constitutive model presented in the previous section cannot be used directly. However, the experimental considerations can simplify this problem. Because of the superior heat conductivity of metal and randomly scattered phase transformation progress in SMAs, a uniform evolution of the temperature can be assumed inside the material. It is equivalent to assume infinite heat conduction rate inside the SMAs, and heat flux is faster than the usual mechanical loading rate. For example, Cu-based alloys such as CuAlZn deform homogeneously in the specimen where internal heat sources can be assumed as homogeneous and continuous during the forward/reverse phase transformation. This assumption can also be used in other two cases: one is the case of short specimen (such as 17 mm gauge length of NiTi sheet (He et al., 2010) or 3 cm length of NiTi strip in this article), and the other is the relatively fast loading rate that leads to numerous nucleations that occur along the length simultaneously (Shaw, 2000; Zhang et al., 2010).

The internal heat source can usually be dissipated by convection, radiation, and conduction. Due to the small area of the specimen, the dissipation by radiation is negligible as well as radial conduction. For conduction through the test machine grips, since the samples are fixed on cardboard with epoxy glue that makes a good thermal insulation (prescribed heat flux or Neumann boundary conditions), it is assumed to be negligible as well (He and Sun, 2011; Piedboeuf et al., 1998; Zhu and Zhang, 2007). So the only significant heat dissipation process considered in this article is the convection process (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of heat exchange between one-dimensional SMAs and the ambient conditions.

sec.p: Based on the first law of thermodynamics, the heat equation is

where θ(t), θ0, CV, h, P, A, and q are the specimen temperature, the ambient temperature, the heat capacity per unit volume, the heat convection coefficient (with air), the cross-sectional perimeter, the cross-sectional area, and the internal heat source rate, respectively. To simplify, P and A are assumed to be independent of x, and the material constants CV and h are assumed to be identical for austenite and martensite.
Before the forward phase transformation, the temperature of the specimen equals the ambient temperature. Hence, the initial condition at the beginning of the forward phase transformation is
The solution of equations (9) and (10) is
where tG=ACV/Ph is defined as the characteristic time of specimen (He and Sun, 2011).

sec.title: Evolution of temperature in the forward phase transformation process (stage A1B1)
sec.p: In stage A1B1, the internal heat source mainly includes two parts (He and Sun, 2011; Piedboeuf et al., 1998): one is the release of latent heat source Qr=Λ, and the other is the mechanical dissipation heat source Qd. If this dissipation process is assumed to be uniform, the rate of internal heat source is qF=(Qr+Qd)/tB1, where tB1 is the loading time from point A1 to point B1. To simplify the problem, these values are supposed to be independent of the strain rate and ambient conditions, and the following assumptions are made: (1) tB1 approximately equals the transformation time tT; and (2) the average value of the stress hysteresis H0 made at ambient temperature and a very low strain rate is taken as σB−σC, and Qd is determined as Qd=H0εm/2 and assumed to be constant for all cases. There is no doubt that the hysteresis H0 is highly dependent on the strain rate (He et al., 2010; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995; Tobushi et al., 1998); however, Qd is an order of magnitude smaller than Qr, its influence is not important, hence a constant value Qd=H0εm/2 assumed here is reasonable. Substituting q=qF into equation (11), the temperature of the specimen in stage A1B1 is obtained, and the temperature at point B1 is θB1=θ0+AqFPh(1−e−tT/tG).

sec.title: Evolution of temperature in the elastic unloading process (stage B1C1)
sec.p: In stage B1C1, there is no phase transformation, and q on the right-hand side of equation (9) is zero. Combining the new initial condition t=0,θ(t)=θB1 at the start point B1 of unloading, the temperature of the specimen in stage B1C1 is obtained as

To continue the analysis of temperature variation in the reverse phase transformation stage C1D1, the temperature of the specimen at point C1 should be obtained. The elastic unloading time from point B1 to point C1 is
For simplicity, it is assumed that the elastic unloading strain from point B1 to point C1 equals the strain from point B to point C and constant for all cases
Finally, the elastic unloading time from point B1 to point C1 reduces to tU=εU/ε·, and the temperature of the specimen at point C1 is θC1=θ0+(θB1−θ0)e−tU/tG.

sec.title: Evolution of temperature in the reverse phase transformation process (stage C1D1)
sec.p: In stage C1D1, the internal heat source also mainly includes two parts: one is the absorption of latent heat source Qa=−Λ, and the other is the mechanical dissipation heat source Qd=H0εm/2. Similar to the case of the forward phase transformation, the rate of internal heat source here is qR=(Qa+Qd)/tD1, where tD1 is the unloading time from point C1 to point D1 and approximately equals tT. Substituting qR into equation (9) and using the new initial condition t=0,θ(t)=θC1 at the start point C1 of the reverse phase transformation, we have
and the temperature at point D1 is obtained as θD1=θ0+AqRPh+(θC1−θ0−AqRPh)e−tT/tG

sec.title: Variation of damping capacity with respect to the strain rate
Isothermal damping capacity of SMAs
sec.p: At a very low strain rate, the loading–unloading process can be seen as quasistatic and in fact slow enough to dissipate the internal heat with the ambient conditions. This response is nearly isothermal, and the SMAs temperature approximately equals the ambient temperature. In stage OA (see Figure 1), the superelastic SMAs are fully austenite, and the deformation is elastic. When the driving force dλ increases to dλ+ at point A, the macro martensite phase deformation begins to occur and then subsequently deform in the forward phase transformation. According to equation (8), the tensile stress at point A is

In stage AB, the tensile stress in this quasistatic stage is similar to the propagation stress and is consistent with σA due to the rate-independent driving force used in this article. At point B, the martensitic phase transformation is completed, and the tensile stress is σB=σA. If the loading process goes on, the SMAs response is elastic until the tensile stress reaches to the plastic yield stress σy.

In stage BC, the unloading response is nearly elastic, and no conspicuous austenitic phase transformation is observed until the driving stress decreases to dλ− at point C. Similar to equation (16), the tensile stress at point C is

The analysis of the reverse stage CD is the same as the forward stage AB. The tensile stress at point D, where the austenitic transformation has been completed, is σD=σC. Finally, the isothermal damping capacity of SMAs, the hysteresis area SABCD of the stress–strain curve under quasistatic loading, is obtained as

sec.title: Linear model for rate-dependent damping capacity of SMAs
sec.p: The linear model mainly focuses on the starting/ending points of the forward/reverse phase transformation and neglects the complex intermediate process. And the stress–strain curve is simply assumed to be linear between the forward/reverse starting point A1/C1 and ending point B1/D1 (see Figure 3). This idea of simple schematic diagram can also be found in Tanaka (1986).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of linear model and nonlinear model.

sec.p: In the elastic loading stage OA1, the effects of the strain rate on the stress–strain curve are neglected, and the phase transformation stress is assumed to be identical for point A1 and point A. In practice, some preferred-orientation single crystals in the SMA polycrystalline have already transformed into martensite before the macro martensitic phase transformation at point A1. At high strain rates, the specimen does not have enough time to dissipate internal heat generated by the transformed crystals with the ambient conditions, and the macronucleation stress (or propagation stress) at point A1 is larger than σA. This rate-dependent nucleation stress behavior is beyond the scope of this article.

Unlike the quasistatic loading process, the specimen has idealized fully transformed into martensite at point B1 rather than point B. This critical point B1 indicates that if the loading process goes on, the stress–strain curve will be along the line BC, where the specimen is fully martensitic phase. The tensile stress at point B1 is
In the elastic unloading stage B1C1, the effects of the strain rate on the fully martensite are neglected. The tensile stress at point C1 is
Similarly, the tensile stress at the ending point D1 of the reverse phase transformation is
Then the rate-dependent damping capacity of SMAs is

sec.title: Nonlinear model for rate-dependent damping capacity of SMAs
sec.p: To revise the linear stress–strain curve in stages A1B1 and C1D1, the nonlinear model is taken into account (see Figure 3). For the elastic stages OA1 and B1C1, both models are the same; for the phase transformation stages A1B1 and C1D1, the temperature-dependent tensile stress given in equation (8) is used to describe the evolution of the tensile stress with temperature variation in the nonlinear model. And the temperature of the specimen in stages A1B1 and C1D1 are given in equations (11) and (15), respectively. Hence, the nonlinear stress–strain curves in stages A1B1 and C1D1 can be obtained. Finally, the damping capacity presented in the nonlinear model is the sum of the value (equation (22)) of damping capacity presented in the linear model and the areas encircled by the linear and the nonlinear stress–strain curves in stages A1B1 and C1D1, respectively.

sec.title: Modeling of rate-dependent stress–strain curve
sec.p: Both the linear model and the nonlinear model are used to simulate the rate-dependent stress–strain curve of NiTi SMA strips, and comparisons of numerical results and experimental data (Zhang et al., 2010) are given in Figure 4. The material parameters are listed in Table 1. Note that parameters AS and MS, which can be obtained from the DSC curve, were not directly given in Zhang et al. (2010) since the experiment mainly focused on the rate-dependent stress–strain curve, surface morphology, and temperature fields of a NiTi strip. Here, they are obtained by using equations (16) and (17), respectively, to fit the forward and reverse propagation stresses in the quasistatic stress–strain curve presented in Zhang et al. (2010). At a low strain rate of 1.1 × 10−4 s−1, Figure 4(a) shows excellent agreement between experiments and simulations. In this case, the specimen has enough time to dissipate heat with the ambient condition (predominance of convective heat transfer) and the temperature variation is small. The temperature-dependent tensile stress almost remains constant during the forward/reverse phase transformation.

caption.p: Experimental versus numerical stress–strain curves for different strain rates: (a) 1.1 × 10−4 s−1, (b) 1.1 × 10−3 s−1, (c) 1.1 × 10−2 s−1, and (d) 1.1 × 10−1 s−1.
NiTi SMAs material parameters in the discussion.

sec.p: At a higher strain rate of 1.1 × 10−3 s−1 (Figure 4(b)), a negligible disagreement is observed for tests in air. The disagreement can be partly explained by the localization of phase transformation, which does not necessarily occur uniformly over the test sample. For example, the higher strain rate leads to the larger temperature variation. If the temperature-dependent propagation stress on moving phase interface is larger than the nucleation stress on the coolest point of specimen, a new nucleation will occur (He and Sun, 2010; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1997). This localized deformation makes the temperature profile in the specimen is nonuniform.

When the strain rate increases to 1.1 × 10−2 s−1 (Figure 4(c)), the disagreement between experiments and simulations is obvious. This large disagreement can also be partly explained by the localized deformation of NiTi SMAs, which gives an abrupt increase of temperature toward the beginning of the transformation on the moving phase interface, and the temperature gradually decreases near the phase interface. The two models, however, use a uniform temperature variation in the specimen. Moreover, the reverse phase transformation stress in this article is larger than the experimental data because the idealized full phase transformation is used in both models. The displacement-controlled experiments stretched the specimen to a given strain amplitude (8% in the experiment or position B in Figure 3) for different strain rates; however, full martensitic transformation can only be obtained at point B1, where εB1>εB.
Similar observations can be made regarding the stress–strain curves at 1.1 × 10−1 s−1 (Figure 4(d)), where the difference between the simulation and experimental data becomes particularly obvious.

sec.title: Modeling of rate-dependent damping capacity
sec.p: In Figure 4, it can be found that the damping capacity varies nonmonotonously with the strain rate. The same conclusion may be drawn from the experiments (He et al., 2010; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995) and has already been analyzed by many researchers (He and Sun, 2011; Morin et al., 2011; Piedboeuf et al., 1998; Vitiello et al., 2005; Zhu and Zhang, 2007). Here, both the linear model and the nonlinear model are used to simulate the evolution of the damping capacity with respect to the strain rate, and comparisons with experimental data (Zhang et al., 2010) and previous model (He and Sun, 2011) are given in Figure 5.

caption.p: Evolution of the damping capacity with the strain rate.

sec.p: For the low strain rate (the heat convection time is very long), the damping capacity (the area of the hysteresis loop) is practically the same as in the quasistatic case. This is because the temperature variation of SMAs is very small in this isothermal condition, and the effects of the strain rate on mechanical responses of SMAs can be neglected. For the moderate strain rate, the temperature of the specimen oscillates around the ambient temperature, producing a stress–strain response partly above and partly below the quasistatic stress–strain curve. This can result in larger damping capacity. In this case, the nonlinear model simulations are quantitatively in agreement with the experimental data and the model proposed by He and Sun (2011). However, the linear model simulations are significantly smaller than that of other two models and experimental data (see Figure 5). The discrepancy can be easily explained by the linear simplification in Figure 3. For the high strain rate (the heat convection time is very short), the temperature variation is very large. Although the tensile stress caused by high temperature in the forward phase transformation is very large, the tensile stress in the reverse phase transformation is also larger than that of the low strain rate. Therefore, the damping capacity does not change monotonously with the strain rate. Since the idealized full phase transformation is used in both the linear model and the nonlinear model (see the analysis of Figure 4(c)), their numerical results are larger than experimental data and the damping capacity obtained by He and Sun (2011), which is the product of the average stress hysteresis and the phase transformation strain. In fact, the phase transformations in the linear model and the nonlinear model are fully finished at point B1 rather than point B, making larger strain and hysteresis loop.

The maximum damping capacity (damping peak) directly depends on the ambient conditions and the geometry of the specimen, for instance, different experimental conditions (in air or in water) may obtain different results. Compared with experiments in air, the damping peak of NiTi SMAs is achieved with higher strain rate (Morin et al., 2011; Shaw and Kyriakides, 1995). He and Sun (2011) showed that the nonmonotonic rate-dependent damping capacity is governed by the competition of phase transformation time (or latent heat release/absorption time) and the time of heat exchange with the environment and that the peak is achieved when the two time scales become comparable. In water, larger convection coefficient leads to less characteristic time of the specimen, and a smaller phase transformation time is needed to make these two time scales become comparable in order to achieve the damping peak.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The linear model and the nonlinear model based on the rate-independent driving force in the micromechanics-inspired constitutive model (Sadjadpour and Bhattacharya, 2007) are used to simulate the rate-dependent damping capacity of one-dimensional superelastic NiTi SMAs. The quantitative and qualitative comparisons between experiments and simulations at low strain rates show good agreement for both stress–strain curve and damping capacity. However, for high strain rates, the agreement is achieved only qualitatively. The discrepancy may be partly explained by the localized deformation of NiTi SMAs that makes nonhomogeneous temperature profile in the specimen, but the uniform temperature variation is used in this article. Moreover, the models in this article take the idealized full phase transformation for the analysis of damping capacity, while the displacement-controlled experiments stretched the specimen to a given strain amplitude for different strain rates. The linear model is a simplified case of the nonlinear model and can be easily used in practical engineering for its simplicity, and the physical meaning of the nonlinear model is clear. Compared with previous work, both models using fewer material parameters can also quantitatively describe the trend of the variation of damping capacity with respect to the strain rate.
